The Pros and Cons of Expressways



this purpose would be more than could reasonably be expected to be con-
structed within the foreseeable future. But a feasible program of express-
ways could be expected to reduce rush hour traffic somewhat on major
streets and to cause a substantial drop in rush hour traffic on secondary
streets.

Because traffic congestion is at its worst during the two peak hours
in the early morning and in the late afternoon we tend to concentrate our
attention on this rush-hour traffic. Equally important in its blighting
effect on residential neighborhoods is, however, the fact that heavy
through traffic continues on many streets all during the day and evening
and in some cases (e.g. Franklin and Mulberry Streets) virtually all
around the clock. An expressway system which lacks the capacity to
handle all through traffic during rush hours may well have the capacity to
handle all, or virtually all, through traffic during non-rush hours. The
really dramatic effect of expressways in relieving existing streets will thus
probably occur during non-peak hours.

Heavy truck traffic through the City represents a special aspect of
the blighting effect of traffic. This situation was recently highlighted in
Baltimore by a series of regulations issued by Mr. Henry A. Barnes, Com-
missioner of Transit and Traffic, controlling truck traffic in the Northeast
Baltimore. Under the heading of Blight Prevention the Sun for August 5,
1959, commented editorially as follows:

“While urban renewal is not his field, Mr. Henry Barnes is
working for that branch of government in curbing truck traffic on
thoroughfares in new residential areas. Truckers may not see it that
way, but to outsiders it is painfully clear that if Mr. Barnes failed
to give homeowners in Northeast Baltimore some relief from the
thundering herd of night crawlers, the area in a few years’ time
would become the subject of costly blight-eradication programs.

“Unlike the railroads, the trucks have no right-of-way of their
own. If they snarl traffic at busy hours, no local government forces
them to build an overpass or underpass, as is the case with their
rival form of heavy freight carriers. The trucks depend on the
public streets. The public has the right to impose restrictions on
their use of these streets out of consideration for the general welfare.
Mr. Barnes has been acting in accordance with the larger consid-
eration, and in preserving the peace and quiet of residential areas he
is saving the city the grief that comes when it must take action after
a neighborhood has gone downhill.”

Without in any way minimizing the importance or desirability of
Mr. Barnes’ action, it is appropriate to note that while the City has the

- power to regulate truck traffic it cannot wholly bar trucks from City

streets. Eliminating trucks from some surface streets may simply push
them over on to other surface streets. The tendency is for truck routes
to end up passing through those areas having the least articulate occu-
pants. These again tend to be the older blighted areas of the City. Truck
regulations may protect the newer better neighborhoods of the City, but
often at the expense of efforts to renew the older sections. Actions which
further the Urban Renewal Program in one area may serve to impede
it in others.

Again, expressways can help to solve the problem. To the extent that
heavy truck movements can be confined to expressways they can be totally
barred from residential streets. No system of expressways can ever be
complete enough to handle all truck movements within the City, but a
